ranked_diseases.explanation: LCA is characterized by severe visual impairment from birth, nystagmus, and eye poking (oculodigital sign). The very low visual acuity and hypermetropia are consistent with this diagnosis in a 2-year-old.
Another subtype of LCA with similar presentation including congenital blindness, nystagmus, and oculodigital sign. Caused by mutations in RPE65 gene.
CEP290-related LCA presenting with severe early-onset retinal dystrophy, nystagmus, and characteristic eye poking behavior.
Complete color blindness with severely reduced visual acuity, nystagmus, and photophobia. Hypermetropia is common. Eye poking less typical but can occur.
X-linked disorder with nystagmus, reduced visual acuity, and myopia/hypermetropia. Eye poking is less common but the other features fit.
Presents with nystagmus, reduced visual acuity, and refractive errors. Eye poking is not typical but severe visual impairment in early childhood could lead to this behavior.
Can present with early-onset retinal dystrophy, nystagmus, and hypermetropia. Eye poking may occur due to severe visual impairment. Other systemic features may develop later.
